create_optical.ponder.opticals.base.head: Transmitting Rotational Force with Light
create_optical.ponder.opticals.base.text: Optical sources transform rotational force into light
Optical receptors can transform the received light into rotational force
Tinted glass, non-transparent blocks and entities can block the light
create_optical.ponder.opticals.beam_type: Optical sources can propagate different types of light depending on the given rotational force
Higher the frequency, lower the range of the beam.
Caution with higher frequencies, entities can be hurt by the beam.
create_optical.ponder.opticals.mirror.te: Encased mirrors can propagate the incident beam perpendicularly.
You can rotate it to make the beam propagate wherever you want
create_optical.ponder.opticals.polarizin: Polarizing Beam Splitter blocks can split the beam in two polarized beams.
One of them will propagate straight and be vertically polarized.
The other one of them will propagate perpendicularly and be horizontally polarized.
Propagated beams have certain properties. One of them, is the polarization.
This receptor is receiving a randomly polarized beam. This means that the beam is not oscillating in a preferred direction.
Polarizing filters can change the polarization of the beam and its intensity.
Regardless of the direction of polarization, if the ray is randomly polarized it will always reduce its intensity by half.
You can combine polarizing filters to get your desired intensity. Keep in mind that polarizing a beam perpendicularly will nullify its intensity.
The initial polarization can be configured in the source panel.
create_optical.ponder.opticals.sensor.te: Optical sensors emits redstone signal if a beam hits it.
The emitted signal is reduced based on the intensity of the incident beam.
create_optical.ponder.tag.opticals.descr: Components which work with optical beams.
